column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=The odour, for instance, of a distiller’s fermentation, who works from a mixture of raw corn
#Text=and malt, is always as different as night from
#Text=day, from that of a brewer’s, who has a sound
#Text=fermentation, and works with good malt.
#Text=The
#Text=first has always a foetid odour, while that of
#Text=the other is highly vinous, pungent and aromatic.
#Text=I have already said, that the nose is
#Text=almost a sure guide to an experienced brewer,
#Text=in ascertaining whether his fermentation is going
#Text=on well or ill.
#Text=But I would wish to impress
#Text=this point more particularly on the mind, than
#Text=I have perhaps formerly done.
#Text=An experienced
#Text=brewer with a very sensitive smell, should be
#Text=able to judge even by walking through a
#Text=brew-house, whether or not it is in trim, and
#Text=I again repeat that no man who has not both
#Text=a very sensitive smell and taste, can be a
#Text=good brewer.
#Text=Many I know will say that this
#Text=is a fanciful idea.
#Text=But how often do we see
#Text=that even one man, who is acknowledged to have
#Text=a good taste for wine or beer, will guide the
#Text=opinions of a large majority in any company, as
#Text=to the good or bad qualities of the beverage
#Text=they are then drinking.
#Text=The majority, perhaps,
#Text=are not the best judges ; indeed I have seen men
#Text=so devoid of both taste and smell, that it made
#Text=very little difference, whether putrid or fresh
#Text=food were presented to them.
